description.narrative: - % of national coverage by climate monitoring system - frequency of data transmission and reception of current weather and river levels in Tanzania meteorological agency and the water basin authorities, - % of population with access to climate information and improved flood and drought warnings % of which are women, - type of development planning framework informed by climate information in Meru and Liwale districts,

comment.narrative: 50% project of the territory is covered by some form of weather monitoring, but only 30% by automated weather stations. River stations are read manually every 2 hours during rain fall but data is transmitted at various frequencies depending on observer capacity. Tanzania meteorological net work operates at various frequencies with most rapid transmission being hourly from the automated weather stations and slowest being daily manual readings transmitted on weekly basis. ) people in the project sites have access to improved climate information, drought or early warnings, high level frameworks include climate change and mitigating measures but no plans at local level

• Flood forecasting model using rainfall and river flow data in Pangani and Ruvuma Basin Water developed • Standard Operating Procedures for droughts and floods in consultation with all partners at national and local level, including NGOs and the media developed • An integrated database of climate/hydro information that can be accessed by sectoral users in real time, housed in TMA established • Midterm Review of Strengthening Climate Information and Early Warning Project conducted

• Flood forecasting model using rainfall and river flow data in Pangani and Ruvuma Basin Water not yet completed. However the installation of 20 Automated Weather Stations (AWS) has started; TMA completed the survey areas for installing AWS. As of end of Q4 - four stations have been completed, six stations have technicians on-site while the remainder have the system on-site awaiting installation. In Ruvuma and Southern Coast Basin, work is still on-going for 5 new hydro-metric stations in five rivers and ten automatic rainfall gauges in ten villages distributed in four districts. In Pangani River Basin construction is on-going for ten mini-weather stations. Majority of installed weather stations are transmitting data to Pangani server based in Moshi.
• Standard Operating Procedures for droughts and floods in consultation with all partners at national and local level, including NGOs and the media was developed for Arumeru and Liwale. Stakeholder workshop on the SOP was held 16th December for review and the final Standard Operating Procedures for droughts and floods was presented to PMO on 28th December.
• An integrated database of climate/hydro information that can be accessed by sectoral users in real time, housed in TMA still under development. However, in August, data training was conducted with the purpose of enhancing the capacity of Numerical Weather Prediction experts at Central Forecasting Office to adopt data assimilation technique in Weather Research and Forecasting model (WRF) using available computing facilities at Julius Nyerere International Airport for improving the accuracy of the model forecasts. This data assimilation technique will further use local observation station networks which include SYNOP data from TMA manual stations, radio sound data and the AWS of the CIEWS project. The technical training was aimed at enhancing the capacity of the TMA to reduce the impacts of extreme weather in context of Disaster Risk Reduction through provision

• Flood forecasting model using rainfall and river flow data in Pangani and Ruvuma Basin Water developed • Rescue, digitize and achieve relevant available historical data from all ministeries relevant to the 2 pilot districts to be integrated in the global database • Standard Operating Procedures for droughts and floods in consultation with all partners at national and local level, including NGOs and the media developed and Emergency Preparedness and Response Plans (EPRPs) of Liwale and Arumeru districts in place. • Support TMA in the Inspection and configuration of the 36 new AWSs • Crowd sourced hazard feedback platform is installed • Climate Change and Climate Hazards included in local development plans and land use plans in Liwale and Meru districts.

• The project has made some progress on the installation of flood forecast management system. Working together with UNDP Multi-Country Support Programme to Strengthen Climate Information and Resilient Development in Africa (CIRDA), Ministry of Water and Irrigation and the Tanzania Meteorological Agency, the BRLi Company Limited, a France consultancy firm, has been hired to install the hydrological solutions for integrated Water Resources Management System (IWRMS) in Ruvuma and Pangani basins. The assignment commenced in June 2017. The BRLi team met with stakeholders to identify the needs, checking the stations, data quality controls, transmissions, existing systems and data storage to provide the foundation for installing the IWRMS system in Tanzania. The process of designing the system is still progressing.The system will ready for use in June 2018. Pangani River Basin and Ruvuma and southern Coast basin has selected to the two pilot basins where the IWRMS will demonstrated and in future be upscaled to whole country. This will enhance the early warning system in Tanzania and support the identification of the most vulnerable areas for drought and floods. This is among of the key products the project needs to generate to support decisions and development of long term development plans for the pilot districts
• The project has supported the data rescuing, digitization and archiving of historical data relevant for Arumeru and Liwale districts. The data has been shifted from papers to electronic format. The project has assisted the TMA to procure equipment for data digitization (Computers and software, furniture and printer to support the digitisation process. The selected climatological data from TMA relevant Arumeru and Liwale were digitised. The process of migrating the data to national database is still progressing.The project has finalised the establishment of a national integrated database for climate and hydrology information. comment.narrative:
30 of people in the project sites have access to some climate information but no people in the project sites have access to improved climate information drought or early warnings
TAFSIP MKUKUTA II and other high level frameworks include climate change and mitigating measures but no plans at local level

At least 70 of residents in the targeted areas benefit from improved climate information drought or early warnings
Local land use plans and development plans in Meru and Liwale include climate change risk information

Indicator 1
Finalized feasibility study on the setup of a 24hour emergency operation centre EOC within the Prime Ministers Office Disaster Management Department PMODMD The study includes background information on the management of the EOC its functions and structure and personnel requirements the required technical expertise and equipment communication equipment criteria for site selection possibilities to engage with the private sector for longterm sustainability list of agenciesstakeholders including their roles and estimated budget The EoC will be a central command and control facility responsible for carrying out the principles of emergency preparedness and management in the country
Mobilizing local disastermanagement committees and CBOs to participate in the simulation exercise and crowdsourcing through consultations and training
Facilitating field visits and stakeholder consultations to understand how users of early warning advisories use the information for managing climate and weatherrelated risks and how their decision frameworks affect the interpretations of advisories and warnings
The project commissioned a study to assess the efficiency of the available explicit and implicit operating procedures for issuing early warnings The study provided background information on the status of the Tanzania Emergency and Preparedness Plan and a basis for the development of Standard Operating Procedures SOPs for droughts and floods The SOPs will highlight each partners roles and responsibilities the types of early warning messages the appropriate responses the resources and communication pathways to reach local communities The project has initiated the process of developing the SOPs The 1st draft for the Liwale district is done and it focuses on the processes to be undertaken by all stakeholders in their efforts to mitigatecope with floods and droughts
Indicators 1 and 2
Trained 273 and 157 community representatives from the Liwale and Arumeru district respectively The 273 community representatives were trained as trainers for trainers The trainers were given the responsibility to disseminate their knowledge and skills to their fellow village members The training sessions focused on the use of climate information to overcome droughts and floods and on the downscaling of climate information at the local level More than 70 of the community members of the targeted villages will be exposed to the improved knowledge Ultimately its application to the development of village plans will contribute to the development of district development plans The training was extended to 30 district sector heads of the Liwale district and 28 sector heads of the Arumeru district

50 of the territory is covered by some form of monitoring but only 30 by AWS
River stations are read manually every 2 hours during rainfall but transmitted at various frequencies depending on the observers capacity automatic river gauges transmit every 30 minutes TMA network operates at various frequencies with most rapid transmission being hourly from AWS and slowest being daily manual readings transmitted on a weekly basis

75 of national territory is covered by an automated network
Data from river stations transmitted every three hours to TMA every 30 minutes to the WBAs Data from automatic weather stations received by TMA every three hours basis and from manual stations on a daily basis

A technical working group composed of technical teams from Tanzania Meteorological Agency TMA Ministry of Water MoW Ministry of Agriculture Food Security and Cooperatives Prime Ministers Office Disaster Management Department Pangani Basin Water Board and Ruvuma and Southern Coast Water Board was established and became operational The team is discussing various protocols which will enable data sharing and show how end users can benefit from weather services

Indicator 1 The target of the project is to add 36 automatic weather stations of which 16 have already been installed In collaboration with TMA the project is now at the final stages of procuring the rest of the new 20 AWS The equipment will be delivered and installed by the end of 2016 Moreover to date the project has also procured 10 hydrological stations 50 river gauges and 20 automatic rainfall gauges which have been installed in the Pangani and Ruvuma Basins Under the guidance of UNDP the procurement of the remaining 10 hydrological stations 60 river gauges and 20 automatic rainfall gauges has been initiated Procurement is underway and the equipment will be delivered in 2016 Overall the installation of the hydromet equipment has expanded the hydrometeorological automated network to 62 of the national territory The project is on track to meet the target of 75 by the end of 2015
Indicator 2 The project has just completed phase one of installing the hydromet equipment Data from river stations has started flowing in to the Pangani River Basin headquarters as of July 2015 The TMA is planning to start using the data received from the newly installed AWS in October 2015 after installation is finalized and in compliance with WMO standards 2 field laptops and 2 servers have been procured and delivered to TMA for the calibration of the AWS and for the storage and transmission of data respectively The project has initiated the process of designing an integrated database which will accommodate both climate and hydro data This will strengthen the capacity of key stakeholders to generate and access relevant climate information and also make the data available to end usersThe project will make it possible that all the stations are linked and data is transmitted to the TMA network This will improve data quality and weather forecasts
Working on the country strategy to harmonize data collection with the WMO standards The project is also supporting data rescuing and digitization to make available historical data from all ministries to the 2 pilot districts

comment.narrative:
Baseline for outcome 1: METT scores for the 11 FNRs have an average baseline score of 38%.
Baseline for outcome 2: Revenue (own income) for the network of FNRs have a baseline of <US$10,000 /annum.
• Official Project Launching conducted Involving key stakeholders

The project was launched on 19th March, 2016 by the Minister for Natural Resources and Tourism in Magamba Lushoto. All key stakeholder were involved including UNDP, MNRT/TFS, EAMCEF, The Minister of Natural Resources endorsed proclamation of new NFRs a category of protected area that offers the highest level of protection under the National Forest Act. 8 forest reserves proclaimed as NFRs & proclamation for 4 NFRs is ongoing. Collection of some baseline information completed and a web-based documentation developed tested & can be accessed via http://www.tfnr.tfs.go.tz

- Construction of the ranger posts and administration offices in the target Nature Reserves - Magamba, Mount Rungwe, Minziro, Uzungwa and Chome. - Support exchange visit of the nature reserve staff to protected areas where tourism is high - Manyara, Ngorogoro etc. - Support the communities around the nature reserves to access solar energy through private sector partnership.

- Construction of the ranger posts and administration offices has started and will be completed in early 2018. - At least fifty nature reserve staff were supported to visit high tourism, protected areas. - The handing over of 600 solar lanterns from PANASONIC was done to the TFS. The lanterns are to benefit the communities living around the 12 Nature reserves. Staffing and resources development plans developed and implemented for Basin Water Office, District Authorities and WUAs

comment.narrative:
3 District Plans (Morogoro DC, Muheza and Mkinga) developed but not implemented, 1 (Mvomero) initiated but need resources needed to continue
9 Village Land Use Plans developed but not operational in Zigi Basin
5 Village Land Use Plans developed but not operational in Ruvu Catchment Interagency co-operation is currently very weak or non-existent, no joint vision for SLM in place
2 Environmental Committees – Mabayani Dam
1 Community Association - Uwamakizi
1 Community Association - Wakuakuvyama Zigi: 1 WUA- Zigi-Mkulumuzi (functional, but requires strengthening)
Ruvu: 4 WUAs– Mfizigo Sub-catchment; Lower Ngerengere and Upper Ngerengere A & B (all are non-functional)
226 (Ruvu) and 162 (Zigi)people trained in basic provisions of water-use legislation
1 – The required skills and technologies are identified, as well as their sources but are only partially developed
1 – The required skills and technologies are identified, as well as their sources but are only partially developed
Ruvu Basin: 36 extension officers with fair levels of technical skill, but not enough officers in each ward and lack knowledge of modern SLM and current water and land-use legislation
Zigi (Muheza): 12 extension officers; Technical capacity and knowledge is outdated and there are not enough officers in each ward

Establish functional coordination office, conduct incpetion workshop and inception report produced Identify capacity needs for 5 WUAs office of Zigi-mkulumuzi, mfizigo, Upper ngerengere A&B and lower Ngerengere Develop a common SLM vision and strategy for each catchment, establish catchment committee and formulation of new WUAs and sub-catchment committees. Capacity building on SLM for staff, WUAs and catchment commitees

The Coordination office was established at the Ministry of Water and Irrigation and staff allocated. The inception workshop was conducted on 19th February 2016 and inception report produced. The capacity need Assessment for 5 WUAs was successfully done as planned. The 3 WUAs were formed in Zigi and 1 in Ruvu catchment. The SLM vision and strategy was developed, and the National Land Use Plan Commission was involved in the Land Use Management and plans and the processes are ongoing in both catchments. The capacity building on SLM for staff was partially done, planned to be finalized early next week but for WUAs and catchment committees, this was done through best farming practices through SLM which was conducted by Sustainable Agriculture Tanzania (SAT) in Morogoro.

- Improve water accessibility in the village near the water sources in Zigi and Ruvu catchment. - Formation and strengthened capacity and sustainability of the Water Users Association (WUAs) in Ruvu and Wami catchment. - Improve law enforcement in the catchment areas - Improved income generating activities in the catchment areas. - Create awareness among youth to promote catchment areas

- Water accessibility improved through the water gravity project in collaboration with TANGA-UWASA. A total number of three villages of Kimboza, Mashewa and Shembokeza in Muheza district with more than 3000 people benefiting. - Seven Water Users Associations were successfully formed and strengthened through legal training on water laws and policies governing the water sector and enhanced institutional capacity. - Construction of the police posts in Sakale Village in Muheza district has started, expected to be completed in 2018 - will lead to improved law enforcement in the catchment areas. - Formation of beekeeping groups in rural areas in Morogoro has lead to improved income within Ruvu catchment area. - Formation of environment clubs within schools around the catchment areas to promote conservation of catchment areas.

comment.narrative: As of December 2016, 30 businesses and 14 non-businesses have been recorded as UNGC signatories. As of March 2017, a fully operational UNGC local chapter has not been established and therefore has not been able to effectively support or garner signatories, in adhering to the 10 UNGC principles in Tanzania.

- A UN Global Compact local network is established in Tanzania with capacities to support businesses. - At least 50 businesses (UNGC signatories) are understanding, adhering to and reporting on the 10 principles, with a focus on empowering women and promoting gender equality in the workplace, marketplace and community.

• Capacitated UN Global Compact local network in secretariat Tanzania through hiring of the National Coordinator • Global Compact Network in Tanzania Communication Strategy in place • Global Compact Network in Tanzania Web site updated and well functioned • Awareness created to a total of 33 businesses and non-businesses in Arusha and Kilimanjaro whereby 50% indicated an interest to join the UNGC next year. • Established and functional 3 working groups on Anti-corruption , Environment and Sustainable development goals(SDGs) • Supporting 50 signatories on reporting of their Communication on progress(COP) and Communication on Engagement whereby 15 businesses and 01 non businesses submitted their reports.

description.narrative:
Output 1: Increase the capacity of National Assembly to effectively scrutinize legislation and to monitor government performance in a participatory manner through inviting public hearings Indicators 1) Increased percentage of committees that conduct effective bill scrutiny in line with relevant guidelines 2) Increase in percentage of CSOs, academia, research institutions participating in and engaging with committees in terms of the relevant CSO guidelines.
Output 2: Increase the capacity of the National Assembly to oversee government budget including monitoring of SDGs. 1) Increased number of evidence-based recommendations emerging from Budget Committee reports 2) Increased capacity of Oversight/Watchdog Committees to actively review and oversee expenditure and audit reports
Output 3: Enhance the capacity of the NA to engage stakeholders and seek their input into the work of the NA 1) No of best practices procedures identified and adopted by MP Constituency Offices (CO) 2) Increased public awareness and understanding of parliament role and activities 3) Percentage increase in parliamentary party groups' engagement in issues of interest.
Output 4: The NA is more effectively engaged in strategic leadership, transparency and external engagement 1) Timely and regular submission of Government reports made available to Committees for discussion and analysis 2) A comprehensive professional parliamentary development plan and strategy developed
Output 5: Gender is mainstreamed in all functions of the National Assembly 1) Increased number of oversight and selected sectoral committees demonstrate the capacity and commitment to conduct gender analysis and mainstream gender into policies and bills of the parliament 2) Increased capacity of women Special Seats MPs to execute their legislative, oversight and representational role effectively

comment.narrative: 1) 12% of committees that conducts effective bill scrutiny 2) Capacity of Parliament to network with key stakeholders during law making process was 13.4% 3) The capacity for budget committee to scrutinize bills was at 16% 4) Low quality and fewer field visits depending on availability of funds 5) 50% Members of both Houses have insufficient knowledge about Budget cycle/analysis and oversight activities 6) No comprehensive communication plan exists 7) Data shows that the overwhelming majority (approximately 87%) require capacity building in the use of online and web-based tools . 8) Reports from Government are not submitted in timely manner to committees 9) No comprehensive training strategy for NA professional staff development 10) Capacity to influence gender budgeting in parliament is 8% 11) Capacity of members of Parliament to undertake sensitization on gender equality is 12.4%

1. Parliamentary committees skilled to conduct and deliver efficiently the review of Bills based on public feedback and expert opinion 2. Selected number of committees capacitated and able to monitor government based on public feedback and expert opinion 3. Research department and Library supported with relevant procurement 4. MPs skilled and secretariat capacitated to support efficiently the initiation of Private members’ bills 5. MPs skilled and secretariat capacitated to support efficiently the initiation of Private members’ bill 6. Best practices presented on issues related to Private motions 7. Joint consultations of beneficiary committee with Civil society organizations 8. Presentation of best practices on strengthening of oversight committees’ role on budget cycle, budget analyses 9. Build capacity of Budget Department 10. Relevant committees supported to monitor the implementation of the SDGs 11. Budget Committee engage citizens and independent experts in budget review 12. National Assembly monitors government expenditures Capacity building for all MPs starting from budget committee, LAAC, PAC, PIC 13. Support establishment of research protocols 14. Established best practices pilot program for constituency offices 15. Support Parliamentary Party Groups to strengthen knowledge base for multiparty dialog platforms on issues related to fight against Corruption, environment and climate change, human rights, young parliamentarians’ role 16. NA leadership supported in relationship with Government of Tanzania 17. TA provided to NA to conduct a comprehensive gender and capacity needs assessment, review and evaluation of the institutional structure, operations and procedures of the NA to influence gender sensitive reforms 18. Technical (gender expertize) provided to the NA Secretariat to institutionalize gender mainstreaming and analysis including monitor progress on gender equality in NA.

1.1) Pre-trial detention population (as % of total) 1.2) # of criminal justice sector policies, plans, actions and laws informed by data analysis and public consultation inclusive of women and vulnerable groups

comment.narrative:
1.1) 50% of all prisoners are in custody awaiting trial (16,551) 1.2) TBD
2.1) No adequate normative framework on legal aid in place for protection of women and other vulnerable groups 2.2) No adequate normative framework on legal aid in place for protection of women and other vulnerable groups 2.3) Limited number of individuals have access to legal aid services / Limited public legal information campaign 2.4) Though data are not available, perceptions that around 95% of people in prison have not been legally represented 2.5) Women and other vulnerable groups do not benefit from legal aid, particularly in criminal proceedings 2.6) Inefficient pro-bono system
3.1) 30% of reports submitted on time to UPR, treaty bodies and special procedures 3.2) Limited coordination between AGC, CHRAGG and civil society organizations on UPR monitoring

1. Establish Data on quality, scope and coverage of justice service delivery in the criminal justice sector
2. Establish data and information on National Criminal Justice Forum (NCJF) capacity and operations
3. Identify geographical pilot areas and conduct assessments for improvement of delivery of criminal justice
4. Support the establishment of complaint mechanisms in national institutions (MoCLA, TPS), including review of law and regulations
5. Support dissemination of Legal Aid Act
6. Support Strengthen role of national authorities and civil society to promote and protect human rights and women access to justice

To ensure enhanced justice sector coordination and data management the project supported recruitment of National and International consultants to undertake a comprehensive baseline assessment of the criminal justice sector, and two national consultants to support an internal assessment of NCJF capacity and operations who are expected to start both exercises in January 2018. On the other hand, the project managed to support Joint Inspection Visits to Prisons and Police Holding Cells to MoCLA and office of DPP who visited prisons of more overcrowding and remanding persons accused of serious and non-serious crimes in Iringa, Njombe, and Ruvuma as well as support was provided to CHRAGG for inspection visits to Places of Detention (Police and Prisons) in 8 regions ( Geita, Shinyanga, Simiyu, Kagera, Njombe, Ruvuma, Morogoro and, Dodoma) of Tanzania mainland. Establishment of complaint mechanisms in national institutions (MoCLA, TPS, TPS), including review of law and regulations was successful done including a consultative meeting with Criminal justice sector high level representatives to discuss provision of legal aid in criminal proceedings as required by the Legal Aid Act. Either, in 2017 the project has supported activities for accreditation of paralegal curriculum at law school, including technical consultations, also publication of legal aid materials and support to Legal aid week which went along with launch of the Legal Aid Act 2017. In order to Strengthen the role of national authorities and civil society to promote and protect human rights and women access to justice, support was provided to develop a Five Years' Strategic Plan of CHRAGG, support for organization of interactions and coordination meetings on the implementation of UPR and other Treaty Bodies including the CEDAW, action plans for concerned government stakeholders at central and local level including Zanzibar, Support for establishment of Planning & Coordination Unit, including training on plann

description.narrative: Tanzania has a gender responsive National Strategy, Action Plan & Stakeholder Charter in place for preventing and responding to violent extremism. National Advisory Council in place to ensure inclusive and participatory approach to preparation of National Strategy and Action Plan, and to promote transparency and accountability in Action Plan implementation Prison service supported to develop PVE strategy, and pilot scheme implemented in target area prisons to identify and respond to signs of radicalisation in the prison population. Community-based policing strengthened in the project target areas. accountability of Special Forces improved in target areas. Apprenticeship schemes for individuals established Existing vocational training schemes and other employment-generating projects scaled-up in target areas. National UNV scheme established of peer group mentors in target area ‘hotspots’ Journalists trained in techniques for responsible reporting of violent extremism. National and local radio programmes to mitigate violent extremism reach mass audience. Project communications strategy supports local and national public dialogues Voices of young men and women better represented in national dialogue Religious dialogue facilitated, governance and community engagement of religious institutions at community level strengthened Community early warning and response mechanisms for PVE in place. Study to support development of monitoring and evaluation frameworks for national PVE effort in general, and for first phase of the project Context-specific research undertaken to better inform preparation of National Strategy and Action Plan 2018-2020 Web-based knowledge management platform established as key resource for practitioners working on PVE in Tanzania. Coordination mechanisms Increased rate of women’s participation and leadership in the counter violent extremism response and prevention effort Capacity of Women’s civil Society organizations to prevent and respond to violen

comment.narrative: No National Strategy, Action Plan & Stakeholder Charter No National Advisory Council No PVE training curriculum for community policing No Guidelines in place on youth and PVE No PVE specific community projects in target areasStandard Operating Procedures (SOPs) No apprentice schemes targeting vulnerable youth in target areas. No UNV scheme for vulnerable youth. No national & local radio programmes to mitigate violent extremism Low levels of participation of youth in dialogue platforms Dialogue platforms established; No approved curricula No community early warning and response system. No web-based knowledge management platform on PVE Limited coordination mechanism Low levels of women’s participation & leadership in PVE Low levels of engagement of women on PVE

1. National policy framework and intervention capacities strengthened to address the phenomenon of violent extremism 2. Improved interaction between security providers and local population in target areas 3. Livelihood opportunities increased for “at risk” young women and men in target areas 4. Responsible, quality and conflict sensitive news reporting supported, and public awareness and dialogue around violent extremism promoted. 5. Community resilience to violent extremism strengthened. 6. Understanding of violent extremism in Tanzania improved, better managed, and applied to prevention and response efforts. 7. Gender and women’s active participation across all efforts to prevent & respond to extreme violence is promoted in Tanzania.

This year was the initiation phase of the project, which included included recruitment of project staff; procurement of equipment for the project team and the main partner, the National Counter Terrorism Centre; setting up of the field project offices in Mwanza, Tanga and Zanzibar; commencement of the baseline survey on which the M&E Framework for the project will be based; and signing agreements with UN Women, UNESCO and Responsible Parties on the activities that they would be responsible for under the project.
Activity results are as follows: Some efforts were made to contribute in strengthening the national policy framework and intervention capacities to address the phenomenon of violent extremism where by; - Two research pieces conducted to guide the development of the national strategy and action plan, namely “Research on preventing and countering violent extremism (P/CVE) strategies and good practices,” and a “Desk review of Tanzania-specific preventing and countering violent extremism research.” - A National Advisory Council (NAC) has been set-up to guide the development of the National Strategy and Action Plan, comprised of government representatives, academia, civil society and a representative from a women’s network. - A residential seminar was held on PVE National Strategies and Community Engagement drawing from practical examples from the region, specifically Uganda, Kenya, Somalia, IGAD and SADC. Following the seminar, the NAC plan to develop a roadmap for the development of the Tanzanian National Strategy.
Also in order to improve the interaction between security providers and local population in target areas; A practical training material on PVE is in development by the Tanzania Police Force and UNESCO. The training programme shall be rolled out to the target areas through a cascade training.
Initial support was also provided to increase livelihood opportunities for “at risk” young women and men in target areas where by Mapping of ongoing

1. National Strategy and Action Plan developed. 2. At least one hundred police officers training in PVE. 3. At least one community policing project established in each target area (Mwanza, Tanga, Zanzibar) 4. At least 60 youth trained in entrepreneurship. 5. At least two peace dialogues conducted in each target area (Mwanza, Tanga, Zanzibar) 6. Madrassah curricula finalised and disseminated in at least three regions on mainland and in Zanzibar. 7. At least one piece of research conducted on PVE in Tanzania. 8. At least 10 women CSOs have received training on gender and PVE. 9. Establishment of early warning mechanisms in Tanga, Mwanza and Zanzibar.
